results.title: Green Winter
results.brief_description: Elda Hartley set out to make a film about ageing and realised, as a senior citizen herself, she would make a good subject for her film. She candidly examines her own life - “Its not death that bothers me - it’s the deterioration of my mind and body.” Elda sorts through her experience with other cultures and religions, illustrating certain points from many films, and takes an intimate look at her relationship with her husband, Irving, whose failing health demands her complete attention. A personal, yet comprehensive approach to the issues of aging.

results.title: Green to glory
results.creator_credit: British Pathe Production and Lionel Hoare
results.brief_description: A film about British motor racing, featuring such famous drivers as Jim Clark and Graham Hill. Some of the behind-the-scenes activities of mechanics and designers are shown and the film describes how motor racing leads to improvement in saloon cars. Various types of races are seen, from the amateur hill climb to the professional Grand Prix. Emphasis is placed on the high international reputation of Britain’s designers and drivers.

results.title: Green tea and cherry ripe
results.brief_description: Green Tea and Cherry Ripe tells the story of six Japanese women who married Australian servicemen after the Second World War, their efforts to build new lives in Australia and the challenges they faced in an alien land.

results.title: Green plants and sunlight
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Stanley Croner and Warren Brown
results.brief_description: Illustrates how plants are a direct link to the energy received from the sun. Through the process of photosynthesis, green plants trap the sun’s energy and transform it into food which is stored in stems, roots, seeds and fruit. Green plants living beneath the water surface function in a similar manner. Because the sea supports more plants and life than land, man should be aware of its importance as a potential future food source.

results.title: Green pea harvest prediction
results.brief_description: Describes the system of predicting the actual day on which to pick peas to get the maximum harvest from the crop. Samples are taken periodically to obtain indications of maturity which increases at the rate of twenty units pf measurement per day.

results.title: Green light for the traffic of tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Federal Republic of Germany and Igor Scherb
results.brief_description: Traffic problems in transport in Germany. Planning for modern transport arteria: phased traffic lights; traffic counter cylinder placed under the road surface to measure traffic density and automatically adjusts traffic light to govern traffic flow. Frankfurt has radar system to regulate traffic lights - the first in Germany. Use of television to watch flow and allows police to intervene in heavily congested areas - mobile radar checks to control traffic - construction of autobahn widening of existing roads.

results.title: Green horizons
results.brief_description: Show land in New Zealand damaged by over grazing and bushfires. Reports on the measures taken to reclaim land including extermination of rabbits, contour ploughing and education of farmers in conservation methods.

results.title: Green grows the Mallee
results.brief_description: Describes the work of the Pomona Experimental Farm at Murrayville in Victoria, in the use of underground water. Bores were sunk and yielded ample water but problems had still to be overcome in the preparation of the irrigation area. The manufacturing processes of the Pomona Deep Well Turbine pump illustrate the care and engineering precision in the production assembly and testing of the pump units. Irrigation scheme using bore water provide Mallee farmers with security against the threat of drought.

results.title: Green Gold
results.brief_description: The setting of this film is a small community of farmers who make their living not only from the land but also from the forest. We see many of the complicated links in the chain that brings the products of this forest to the consumer, including transport, milling and processing., The various uses of timber are described. But forests cannot be mined, as can metal deposits. Tress are a crop like any other and must be carefully planted, tended and protected against pests, fires and indiscriminate cutting. At a timber conference, experts of the Food and Agriculture Organization seek a lasting solution to the problem of timber shortage. Unexplored areas of forest resources must be tapped; cultivated forests must be conserved. New machines and techniques will also help in processing and developing the products, Co-operation is the only real chance for world-wide progress in conservation.
